stages.html:
Studios

Studios in Affinity equip you with the right tools for your task. They are dedicated spaces that allow you to harness advanced pixel, layout and vector tools all within a single app.

  • The Vector Studio is great for creating precise curves, editing nodes and combining complex shapes.
  • The Pixel Studio allows you to edit RAW images, add non-destructive adjustments and filters and create digital art using raster brushes.
  • Use the Layout Studio to place images, edit text using advanced typography tools and create beautiful layouts.

Customising Studios

Vector, Pixel, Layout, or all three—mix and match your favourite tools to build your very own creative studio for a streamlined workflow.

  • To supercharge your creative workflow, combine your tools and panels.
  • Alter existing Studios or choose to create new ones.
  • Toggle Studios on and off in the Studio Manager.

Layers & Clipping Masks

Layers in Affinity are very powerful: they allow you to create complex effects effortlessly.

  • Any layer can be a mask, parent or child.
  • Simply drag and drop a layer onto another layer's name to place it inside, or onto a layer's thumbnail to create a clipping mask.
  • Each layer can have its own blend mode, allowing you to control how it interacts with other layers.

Live Filters & Adjustments

Live Filters and Adjustments are non-destructive tools that let you experiment, refine, and perfect your designs in real time.

  • Live filter layers allow you to apply effects to your designs such as blurring, sharpening and distortion.
  • Adjustment layers allow you to adjust color balance, brightness, contrast, hue, saturation and tonal range.
  • By dragging a filter or adjustment layer, you can choose where its effect is applied.

Exporting your document

Affinity's export options give you full control over how your work leaves the app, whether it's by selection, slice, or the whole document.

  • Export any element, selection or document at any time in one click with Quick Export.
  • Use the Export dialog to choose from a wide range of formats and even export to Canva.

In App Learn

Looking for more learning? Click the Affinity icon and explore the Learn tab.

Import your files into Affinity

Affinity makes it simple to import and continue editing your existing files in just a few clicks.

  • Import IDML, PSD, PDF, AI, EPS, SVG and DWG files directly into Affinity.
  • All imported files become editable Affinity (.af) documents.

As you follow this topic, try each step using your own files.

Importing IDML Files

Import IDML files to Affinity in just three simple steps:

  • Go to File > Open.
  • Choose your IDML file.
  • Locate any missing resources or fonts if prompted.

Affinity will handle everything else. Your design becomes a new document, ready to edit and save as an Affinity file.

Quick Tip: Managing document resources
Linked and Embedded resources are a core part of design documents, such as IDML files. At any time, you can go to the Resource Manager under the Document menu to manage your document resources.

Importing PSD and AI Files

  • Open AI, PSD and PSB files directly in Affinity.
  • Layers and artboards stay in-tact and editable.
  • Adjustment layers are automatically mapped to Affinity adjustments and remain non-destructive where possible.
  • Opening AI files will display options for artboards or pages, as well as DPI and colour space.

Importing PDF Documents

Edit PDFs just like any other design.

  • Go to File > Open.
  • Choose the page range, DPI and colour space.
  • You can choose to make text editable, group lines of text into frames and substitute missing fonts if needed.
  • Choose to import as pages or artboards.

Placing Resources

You can place InDesign (IDML), Illustrator, Photoshop and PDF files into any existing Affinity document by simply dragging files into Affinity.

  • Hold Option (Mac) / Alt (Windows) when dragging and dropping a file. You can choose which pages to place.
  • Alternatively, go to File > Place, choose your file and click Open.
  • Click on the document to place the content at its native size.
  • If you have placed a multi page document, you can toggle between the document pages from the options on your Context Toolbar.

In App Learn

Looking for more learning? Click the Affinity icon and explore the Learn tab.

Exporting made easy

Export your designs in the right format for your workflow using any of three different methods:

  • Quick Export Panel: Export your whole document or a selection to your favourite file format. Just pick a preset and go.
  • Export Dialog: Choose from a range of industry-standard file formats and a comprehensive selection of advanced export settings.
  • Slice Studio: Open the Studio Manager to select the Slice Studio. Create multiple slices in a single document, with their own file formats and settings.

Quick Export Panel

Perfect for sharing or saving your work fast.

  • Select the elements you want to export. Your selection can be multiple elements or even an entire artboard.
  • At the top right of the app, click the arrow next to Export to show the Quick Export dialog.
  • Choose your export settings. In this example, we are using PNG.
  • Click Export, set a filename and location, then click Save.

Export Dialog

Use the Export dialog when you want full control over how your document is exported.

  • Go to File > Export > Export.
  • On the dialog that appears, select a file format and preset on the left.
  • Fine-tune and make adjustments to your export by interacting with the settings on the right.
  • Choose a Location from the drop-down menu at the bottom right. We've chosen Ask for Location.
  • Click Export, set a filename and location, then click Save.

Export for Professional Printing

When exporting to PDF, the presets beginning with PDF/X are designed for professional printing.

  • On the Export dialog, select the PDF/X4 preset to output in CMYK with spot colors.
  • Make sure you enable bleed and printer's marks in the settings on the right.
  • Export a file as you learned earlier. Open the PDF to see it includes bleed and printer's marks.

Slice Studio

Export multiple parts of your design at once. You can export artboards, layers, groups, objects, or even custom slices to different file formats and image sizes, all in one go.

  • Use the Slice Selection Tool to select objects. Ctrl-click (macOS) / Right-click (Windows) on the selection and choose Create Slice to create a slice from the objects.
  • Use the Slice Tool to draw a slice. Any area captured in the slice will be included in the export.
  • On the Slices Panel, set each slice's outputs. You can apply custom settings on the Export Options panel.
  • Click Export Slices and choose where to save the output files.

In App Learn

Looking for more learning? Click the Affinity icon and explore the Learn tab.

items.name: Layers
items.description: Learn how to work with layers.

stages.html:
Layers in Affinity

Layers are essential in digital design. Think of them as transparent sheets stacked together, each holding parts of your design such as text, shapes, or effects. They let you edit elements freely and non-destructively, so changes don't affect the rest of your design.

Organising Layers

Managing layers is similar to organising your workspace.

  • Click on a layer to select it, and move it up or down to control what appears in front or behind.
  • Select multiple layers, right-click and select Group to keep related elements together.
  • To prevent changes, hover over the right side of a layer and click the lock icon when it appears.

Creating Clipping Masks

Clipping Masks let you use one shape to reveal only parts of another.

  • On the Layers panel, reveal the Polka Dots layer and locate the Jacket layer above.
  • Drag the Jacket layer onto the thumbnail of the Polka Dots layer. Alternatively, right-click on the Jacket layer and select Create Clipping Mask.

Applying Blend Modes

A layer's Blend Mode controls how a layer interacts with other layers. Blend Modes can darken or highlight layers, add texture or even cause the layer to appear as an overlay, all without altering the original layer.

  • Select the Polka Dots layer on the Layers Panel.
  • Go to the Blend Mode options at the top of the Layers Panel. As you scroll through the options, you will see a live preview showing how each blend mode affects the layer.
  • Select the blend mode Difference to reverse the effects of the Polka Dots.

Live Filters and Adjustments

Live Filters and Live Adjustments apply real-time non-destructive effects you can apply, edit or remove at any time without harming the original layer.

  • At the bottom of the Layers panel, click Adjustments and select HSL.
  • Move the Hue Shift slider and observe the effect taking place in real time.
  • Select the HSL Shift Adjustment layer and drag it over the layer named Objects to place the layer inside.
  • Open the Objects group layer and click on the thumbnail of the HSL Shift Adjustment layer.
  • To edit the HSL Shift adjustment, open the Objects group and click on the HSL Shift thumbnail.

Masking

Masking with raster brushes hides or reveals parts of a layer non-destructively. Black conceals, white reveals, and grey adds transparency, letting you refine or restore any area at any time.

  • Select the Objects group layer and go to the Live Filters icon.
  • Choose the Motion Blur filter and increase the radius to 30px.
  • Select the Pixel Studio and choose the Paint Brush Tool. Select a brush from the brushes panel and set your brush colour to black.
  • With the Motion Blur layer selected, paint over the shoulder sleeve, cap, and feet to mask out the effect.

Quick Tip: Filters and Adjustments include built-in masks, so there's no need to create them manually. This saves time, especially in complex workflows.

In App Learn

Looking for more learning? Click the Affinity icon and explore the Learn tab.

items.name: Live Adjustments and Filters
items.description: Use adjustments and filters in Affinity.

stages.html:
Live Filters and Adjustments

In this topic, we will practice adding live filter layers and adjustment layers to improve the colour, contrast and overall look of your designs.

We will use some of the most commonly applied adjustments and filters, such as Levels and Colour Balance adjustments, as well as Depth of Field Blur and Lighting filters.

Adding Adjustments

An Adjustment Layer is a non-destructive way to change the colour, tone or brightness of your image without permanently altering the original.

  • Add a Levels adjustment layer from the icon on the Layers Panel.
  • Set Black Level to 3% and the White Level to 73% to increase the contrast.
  • Add a Colour Balance adjustment and increase Red to 35% and Blue to 20% to warm the image.
  • Working non-destructively, you can always return to an adjustment if you feel the change is too strong. Return to Levels by clicking on the layer thumbnail and change the White Level setting to 95%.

Live Lighting Filter

A Live Filter Layer is a layer that lets you apply effects such as blurring, sharpening or distortion non-destructively.

  • Select the Portrait layer and add a Lighting filter from the filters icon on the Layers Panel. This will apply your live filter as a child layer to your image.
  • Explore using the filter control handles and sliders to move the light source around the image.
  • Here are the parameters shown in the video:
    • Diffuse: 100%, Specular: 50%, Shininess: 80%, Ambient: 54%
    • Set Colour to a pale yellow
    • Distance: 33%, Outer Cone: 37%, Inner Cone: 55%

Live Depth of Field Blur

We can apply a non-destructive depth-of-field blur to gently soften the edges of the image, drawing more focus to the model's face and subtly separating the model from the background.

  • Select the Portrait layer and add a Depth of Field live filter. Move the control handles to centre it on the face.
  • Increase Radius to 24px to increase the strength of the blur.
  • Increase Clarity to 5px to sharpen the centre of the ellipse.
  • Enable Preserve Alpha to confine the effect to the edge of the image.
  • If closed, expand the Portrait parent layer, then use the visibility icon to toggle the filter on and off.

Quick Tip: You can also use Portrait Blur in the Canva AI studio to achieve this effect. Using Canva AI will incur the use of credits.

In App Learn

Looking for more learning? Click the Affinity icon and explore the Learn tab.

Text in Affinity

Lay out your images, graphics, and text. Make edits directly in your document. Watch it all update live. Fast and feature-packed, Affinity keeps everything in line.

Artistic Text

In the Layout Studio, Affinity provides two main text tools. We will start with artistic text, which is ideal for decorative type treatments.

  • Go to page 4, select the Artistic Text Tool and drag on the page below 'Make A' to create some artistic text. Use the 'A' Symbol to gauge the size of your Artistic Text.
  • Type the word 'Splash'. To resize the text, drag any edge or corner handle.
  • Select the text inside the layer and choose a font from the options on the Context Toolbar. Hovering over a font shows you a preview.
  • Select the Case Options and choose Uppercase.
  • Select the Move Tool to reposition the text on the page. Drag the SPLASH text layer below the Kingfisher layer.

Frame Text

Text frames are containers that text flows through, line by line. It's ideal for body copy, captions, and sidebars.

  • Go to page 6. Select the Frame Text Tool, then drag on the page to create a text frame.
  • To add placeholder text, Ctrl-click (macOS) / Right-click (Windows) in the frame and choose Insert Filler Text.
  • Try resizing the text frame. Notice how the text matches the size of the frame.
  • Using the context toolbar, you can flow the text across multiple columns.
  • To turn filler text into editable text, Ctrl-click (macOS) / Right-click (Windows), then select Expand Field.

Linking Frames

You can link multiple text frames so text flows between them. The frames can have different dimensions and be on different pages. Edited text reflows automatically.

  • Go to pages 8 and 9, then disable View > Preview Mode.
  • Using the Move Tool, select the first text frame, then click the red Text Flow button in the lower right corner.
  • Click inside the second text frame. The text now flows between them.
  • Repeat the process to link the other frames from left to right.
  • Click the Text Flow button on the last frame, then drag in the empty space to create and link a new frame.

Paragraph Styles

Paragraph styles control text appearance such as font, size and colour. They also control paragraph settings such as alignment, spacing, and indents.

  • Use the Frame Text Tool to select a range of text that includes at least two paragraphs.
  • Select a font from the context tool bar and adjust your fonts size.
  • On the context toolbar, select the Paragraph Style menu and choose New Style.
  • On the Create Paragraph Style dialog, name your style.
  • Next, select the Position & Transform category to increase the Leading.
  • To increase the space after the paragraph, go to Spacing > Space After.
  • Making sure Apply style to selection is enabled, choose OK to apply your style.
  • You can now apply your style throughout your document by simply selecting text and applying the text style.

Drop Caps and Initial Words

You can apply drop caps or initial word formatting from the Paragraph panel.

  • Place your cursor at the start of the first paragraph. Go to the Paragraph panel and expand the Drop Caps section, then choose Enabled.
  • Change the Height in lines to enlarge the first letter.
  • Select another paragraph, expand the Initial Words section and choose Enabled.
  • Apply the Strong character text Style. Increase the Max word count for the initial words in the paragraph to appear in bold.
  • You could also choose to save and apply these settings as part of a Paragraph Text Style.

Text Wrapping

You can flow text around objects using the Text Wrap settings:

  • Go to page 12. Using the Move Tool, select the image of the red lizard from the left hand side. Notice that the text currently overlaps the image.
  • Go to Text > Text Wrap > Show Text Wrap Settings.
  • On the dialog that appears, set the Wrap Style to Tight.
  • Adjust the Distance from Text to fine-tune the spacing between the image and text. It may be useful to link the distance from spacing, making the distance between the text and image equal from all directions.

In App Learn

Looking for more learning? Click the Affinity icon and explore the Learn tab.

Image Trace

The Image Trace feature converts a raster image to a vector design. It analyses the edges in the image and uses in-dialog settings to trace around these edges, creating vector curves and shapes.

Some typical scenarios for using the feature include recreating company logos, old assets where the original app is no longer available and scanned copyright-permissible real world designs (e.g., tattoo art, magazine).

Using Image Trace

Converting pixel images to vector.

  • Select the image and go to Vector > Image Trace. This will open the Image Trace dialog.
  • Use the Split and Mirror View Modes to compare the pixel to vector conversion. You can drag the split-view slider left and right over areas of interest.

Fine Tuning Image Trace Results

Modify the settings as required to control the output.

  • The Edge Threshold controls what are considered to be the edges in the image, affecting what vector objects are created.
  • Adjust Curve-fitting Tolerance to smooth or sharpen the vector outlines.
  • Click Apply to commit the conversion.
  • You can now select nodes to make further enhancements or changes to the artwork.

In App Learn

Looking for more learning? Click the Affinity icon and explore the Learn tab.

Embedded Documents and Non-Destructive Editing

In this topic, we will create a mockup with a placed Affinity file, using shapes, the Perspective Tool and Adjustments.

Your project file includes a placed Affinity file. It has been added as shown in the video and hidden for us to use later.

Adding Shapes

Let's create a boundary to contain the placed file.

  • Select the Rectangle Tool and drag a rectangle over the screen.
  • On the Context Toolbar, click the stroke colour well and remove the colour on the stroke.
  • Switch to the Move Tool (V) and select the Perspective Tool from the Sub Tools group.
  • Align the corners of the rectangle with the corners of the screen.
  • When you are happy, close the Live Perspective dialog. This will bring you back to the Move Tool.

Place Inside

  • Make visible the Placed Affinity File layer on the Layers Panel.
  • Drag the Placed Affinity File layer and drop it onto the name of the Rectangle layer. Move and Resize the placed file as required.
  • To edit your placed file, double-click the Placed Affinity File on the document. This will open the file in a separate tab.
  • Double click on the word Don't and change it to That to edit the document.
  • Close the tab and return to your original project file to see the changes applied.

Quick Tip: You can place a new Affinity file, PDF and other file types to swap out your screenshot without recreating the perspective transform.

Apply an HSL Adjustment

  • Deselect all layers by pressing CMD+D (Mac) / Ctrl+D (Windows)
  • Add the HSL adjustment from either Adjustments at the bottom of the layers panel or by going to Pixel > New Adjustment Layer > HSL.
  • This will apply the HSL adjustment to the top of the layer stack. The HSL dialog will open.
  • Edit the HSL parameters as required. This will affect the entire image.
  • Close the HSL panel and drag the HSL Shift Adjustment layer onto the name of the Rectangle layer to place inside.
  • Further changes to the HSL adjustment can be made by opening the layer stack and clicking on the HSL Shift Adjustment thumbnail.

In App Learn

Looking for more learning? Click the Affinity icon and explore the Learn tab.
